dialogues.Gabe: What would you say if someone started a Dear Black People?  I dig the "silent movie" thing, but it's a little self-congratulatory. Light on story and frankly thematically dubious.  Well what was that supposed to be about exactly?  You invoke Minstrelsy for shock value, but to what end?  So it's a tit for tat?                      *  You're reacting to a work made              * almost a hundred years ago.                 *  Frankly I just think sometimes its          * better to hold a mirror up to your          * audience than to drop an                    * ideological piano over their head.          *  African Diaspora? Really?                              *  Who goes to see Tyler Perry movies?  --to the detriment of the so called "real thing." Got it.     And the commodification of culture is uniquely oppressive to Black people?  So when Kanye raps about Louis V and Rolexes and Classical Art, exactly what exploited pocket of Black America are those references being mined from?     What? You dream in "Cosby" again?  Hey so...this whole "Head of House" thing. Congrats?  Weird, right? Never took you as a student politician...  Sam? What are we doing?  Sam! Really Sam?  What is all this?  You want me to tell them to go?  I will.  I'm trying to be here for you.  What do you see in him?  Wow. Okay.  I want to be down? How long does it take to get your hair like that?  --what? Have to pick a side? I'm sick of your tragic Mulatto bullshit Sam!  Mulatto! Mulatto! Mulatto!  I'm sorry if I can't be your Nubian prince on my Black horse ready to take you back to fucking Zamunda!  Can I please get some credit for a solid "Coming to America" reference?  This isn't you Sam.  You're this...girl...  Who...likes to argue with me about every fucking thing. And I hate it because we both know you're smarter than me. Your favorite director is Bergman, but you tell people its Spike Lee. You love bebop, but you've got a thing for Taylor Swift. I know because my Mac picks up your Mac's library.  You like to use phrases from the thirties and wear clothes from the fifties and hairstyles from the sixties. You like to watch me when you think I'm sleeping. And trace the outlines of my face.  You're more "Banksy" than "Barack" but you've been co-opted as some sort of revolutionary leader or something? But really you're an anarchist. A beautiful writer, artist, filmmaker, shit starter. And beautiful, in general.  Everything okay?  Good. That's good Sam.  What!?  Hello Sam.  Read about Armstrong / Parker.  Congrats?  Sam going against the grain? Shocked. How's papa White?  Good. Well...  Want to talk about it?  I'm sure he forgives you.  Sam. Where are you going?  Isn't it Mac and Cheese day at Armstrong/Parker?
dialogues.Helmut: You call your Youtube show "Doing Time at an Ivy League?"  Yeah? And do what?  Armstrong / Parker? That your rooming assignment?  That's not where you want to be?  With the rich white kids.  What part of Chicago you from?  What street?  -- Seventy Eighth is Southside sweetheart. And you know what they say. You can take the girl out the hood but --  Thanks so much for coming in.  Here's the way reality works sweetheart, I'm the producer. I ask the questions. Be in touch.  This is the school radio?  I'm looking for good TV sister.  You're at a great school, getting a great education. Be good at that.  Conflict is a commodity in my industry. Sam's got it. Do you?    New videos are picking up steam.  The show I'm scouting for... It's called Black Face / White Place. It's reality. Like a "True Life." Each episode centers on a different one of "us" in a sea of "them."  Interesting? You think they want interesting? Dignified stories of triumph and survival? They want the "authentic urban experience" which is basically network talk for bitching and weave snatching. I'm telling you this because the network is looking to take one of the subjects to series. I got one episode. One shot to find that subject. So if we do this...  I think so. She called me a Bojangling Oofta, whatever that means. Everything else she said would've been bleeped on tv. So look, forty thousand hits on Youtube is good. It's not great.  They'd let you do that?  It's just...  ...not everyone is as camera ready as you.  Two hundred thousand views. Look they even auto-tuned it.  Couple months, that's how long shooting for an episode takes. We recommend you cut your course load in half to accommodate the schedule.  Trust me it it'll read "full-time" in the episode. If...once we go to series, we might have to figure out a summer schedule.  For uh...classes and stuff. Won't be graduating early anymore sweetheart.  Five grand for the episode. Twenty each if you get picked up for series. What do you say?  Trust me sweetie it's the same out there as it is in here. Good news is? Against all that damn white you and I? We pop. Think I wanted to be the go-to producer for all things Black?  Tell you what's worse though. Being that broke Nigga stuck on the south side of Chicago. Hundred and Fiftieth street.  Let me get this straight. First you tried to break up the Black house. Then you took down the sister with the little radio show. And after all that, your kid throws a Blackface party?  You thought you were having money problems before? Wait till cable gets their hands on this story. Bill Maher is gon' fuck you up!  -- Wait I'm sorry. Look from where I'm sitting this place is a goldmine.  For one we got to show the events that led up to the party --  Well yeah, but we can reenact --  Documentary term...Look, I can start putting together an overall deal today. I'm talking real money! Turns out the one thing America likes in it's reality more than ignant Black folks, is crazy racist White people!

description: A social satire that follows the stories of four black students at an Ivy League college where controversy breaks out over a popular but offensive black-face party thrown by white students. With tongue planted firmly in cheek, the film explores racial identity in acutely-not-post-racial America while weaving a universal story of forging one's unique path in the world.â€”Anonymous
name: Dear White People
